articles.headline: Professional Networking, Minus the Fees
articles.snippet: Soaring costs of professional conferences prompt some entrepreneurs to linger in lobbies, rather than register, to make contact with people who can help their businesses.
articles.abstract: Soaring costs of professional conferences prompt some entrepreneurs to linger in lobbies, rather than register, to make contact with people who can help their businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Justin Gignac wouldn’t miss the annual Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity. But he doesn’t pay.

articles.headline: Surviving Ebola, but Untouchable Back Home
articles.snippet: As some survivors come back to the world of the living, they feel a chill of wariness, or worse, from neighbors.
articles.abstract: As some survivors come back to the world of the living, they feel a chill of wariness, or worse, from neighbors.
articles.lead_paragraph: DARU, Sierra Leone — The neighbors lined up, smiling and mouthing soft congratulations when the van pulled in bearing Jattu Lahai and her 2-year-old daughter.

articles.headline: E-Bike Sales Are Surging in Europe
articles.snippet: Although the United States has yet to significantly embrace e-bikes, they are catching on in countries that already have a strong bicycle culture.
articles.abstract: Although the United States has yet to significantly embrace e-bikes, they are catching on in countries that already have a strong bicycle culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — With a faint electric whir, Iris Marossek pedals her bicycle through concrete apartment blocks in the heart of old East Berlin, delivering mail to 1,500 people a day.

articles.headline: Tax Burden in U.S. Not as Heavy as It Looks, Report Says
articles.snippet: An academic paper argues that the American tax code’s loopholes result in effective rates that make United States corporations more competitive than their competitors based overseas, not less.
articles.abstract: An academic paper argues that the American tax code’s loopholes result in effective rates that make United States corporations more competitive than their competitors based overseas, not less.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, chief executives have complained bitterly about the United States corporate tax code, arguing that it is too complicated and that rates are too high. The issue has reached a near boiling point this summer as many large American companies have sought to buy smaller foreign rivals so they can renounce their United States corporate citizenship and reincorporate overseas to lower their tax bills. Others are considering the move, known as an inversion.

articles.headline: Obama Is Seen as Frustrating His Own Party
articles.snippet: President Obama appears remarkably distant from his own party on Capitol Hill, Democrats there say, leaving him with few loyalists as issues erupt abroad and at home.
articles.abstract: President Obama appears remarkably distant from his own party on Capitol Hill, Democrats there say, leaving him with few loyalists as issues erupt abroad and at home.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The meeting in the Oval Office in late June was called to give President Obama and the four top members of Congress a chance to discuss the unraveling situation in Iraq.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse, Jeremy W. Peters and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Cities Rocked by Past Protests Offer Lessons in What, and What Not, to Do
articles.snippet: Big-city police officials have learned that the speedy release of information and close ties to community leaders are crucial to stemming violence in disturbances like those in Ferguson.
articles.abstract: Big-city police officials have learned that the speedy release of information and close ties to community leaders are crucial to stemming violence in disturbances like those in Ferguson.
articles.lead_paragraph: The trigger for civil unrest in Ferguson, Mo. — the fatal shooting of an unarmed black man by a police officer — has also provoked riots in American cities both small and large in the last two decades. But few of those disturbances were as stubbornly resistant to resolution as the Missouri protests, which now have drawn the National Guard and even the White House into efforts to restore calm.
articles.byline: By Michael Wines and Erica Goode

articles.headline: National Guard Troops in Ferguson Fail to Quell Disorder
articles.snippet: Violence erupted in Ferguson, Mo., once more overnight, even as National Guard troops arrived in the latest in a series of attempts to quell the chaos after a police officer fatally shot an unarmed teenager.
articles.abstract: Violence erupted in Ferguson, Mo., once more overnight, even as National Guard troops arrived in the latest in a series of attempts to quell the chaos after a police officer fatally shot an unarmed teenager.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Violence erupted here once more overnight, even as Missouri National Guard troops arrived, the latest in a series of quickly shifting attempts to quell the chaos that has upended this St. Louis suburb for more than a week.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey, John Eligon and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: Two Good Omens for Housing Market
articles.snippet: Home construction increased sharply in July, the Commerce Department reported on Tuesday, as Home Depot, whose fate is tied closely to the housing market, announced a strong quarter.
articles.abstract: Home construction increased sharply in July, the Commerce Department reported on Tuesday, as Home Depot, whose fate is tied closely to the housing market, announced a strong quarter.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a harsh winter, the nation’s modest housing recovery appears to be back on track.
articles.byline: By Dionne Searcey and Elizabeth A. Harris
